safety_actions.Action/Recommendation: I'm sure most drivers will agree with me on this one.A lately signals have been playing up all over the system. Until they are fixed properly is there a chance we could have permission to go through Green and bar signal that have NO conflicting traffic moves when in this phase, for example; Infirmary road/Flora street, infirmary Road/Albert Terrace Road, West street/Carver street, West street/Holly Street, Etc. Not only would it help drivers run on time, it would benefit OCC as they would not get as many calls regarding signals. - Allow drivers to go through Green and bar at NON-CONFLICTING Junctions. (No conflicting traffic moves)
safety_actions.Comments: This concern has been considered by JK SG &SG  and  it has been identfied that the safest option is to continue reporting green & bar and working under OCC instruction, to note the timetable is not considered priority when tramway signalling causes an issue.

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation: Platform lighting comes on 30 mins after going dark. Massive safety concerns, pulling into a busy unlit platform, anyone sat on edge platform, too close edge, can't see back of platform when shut the doors etc etc.  Been reported to OCC who say it's a known issue, been reported to Duty Managers.... Nothing gets done. Even know when gets lighter in evening still comes on 30 mins after dark. Stops like Gleadless and Hollisend lighting turns off before midnight when there are still 3 service trams due through - Either regulate all platform lighting to come on when goes dusk or fit sensors to trigger them to come on automatically at dusk.
safety_actions.Comments:
01/02/2024 response sent back to Jlawrie, OCC updated  - Joe/Jack asked in OCC for a list of potential problem areas but none of the controllers on shift were aware of any list.
 
We will attend to any lights reported to us which have a timer issue and if required will disconnect the time clock unit.
 Once disconnected the lights will be illuminated via the Photo-electric cell 24/7 and will switch on/off depending on the ambient light levels at each location.
 
Originally the timers were fitted to the tower lights on each platform to help with energy saving.
Since replacing all the lamps with more efficient LED types there is no longer a need for the timers in circuit.
 
Going forward if there are any locations where the timers fail we will just revert back to relying on the PE cells to control the lighting.

Also require drivers to now inform in lights are on during daylight hours as will indicate photo senso failure and need to be addressed

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation:
The number of bulbs not working/missing in the older style LRT’s now is getting a little ridiculous.   Over a few duty’s covering MAB, HAL, MID, MEH, I roughly counted over 250 bulbs not lit. This does not consider the bulbs on the bar aspects not visible to me. 
Yes, I report any that have all but one/two lit, or in some cases where bar’s are not lit at all, but we cannot report every LRT on a route - s it feasible that a team can go out with a packet of bulbs and a step ladder and fix them route by route, then have a scheduled x-monthly schedule to check/replace? The new LED’s (?) ones being installed are much clearer and reliable
safety_actions.Comments:
Email from N Barraclough - We already have these actions in place for regular sweeps to check the LRT Lamps
It's a regular inspection on xvp ; the issue we are now facing is the lamps we need to replace them with are no longer made.

It may be worth sending the person who sent this a copy of the report I sent you, Josh, explaining why the lamps aren't always the issue. as they seem to believe we don't go and check them!!

The comment about the new LED being better is nice to hear, and I will pass it on to AMEY, who are doing that work, as it will no doubt be pleasing to them.

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation: Hello, not a safety report, but an environmental and money saving suggestion? The upstairs  corridor in the depot is illuminated 24 hours a day/ 7 days a week. When the office staff have left, there are minimal people walking up and down and especially after service ends there is little to no traffic for 4 hours. My suggestion is that we install sensors so the lighting is  only on when someone is actually walking (like is in the upstairs toilets) Clearly don't know if there is legislation around this, but I have witnessed it in many hotels . Thanks for considering this.
safety_actions.Comments: Email from MB 13/02/2024 This is a very valid point and I’m sure this could be done. It might be better passing this BOSRIA to Mark Tompkins and his electrical team to see if this could be achievable. Has been sent to MTomkins & Ilevin - Comments from Mark Tomkins - 04/03/2024 - Mark Tomkins it would not be reasonbabaly practical to fit sensots outside of every office - States that as the light fittings alrready in place are LED they do not use a vast amount of energy and it works out less expensive to leave them them on rather than purchasing sensors to swtich them on/off with occupancy

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation: The sites here on events are dirty and sometimes unsafe if the weather has been bad. at arena the gates are very difficult to slide due to leaves and mud going into the runners and the walkway gets filled with fallen branches and rubbish. at Leppings Lane the barriers and chain collect mud, rubbish and leaves. our hands get filthy - that cleaners go to these areas on the days of events (use the event list that Andy Cullen sends out) and ensure they are clean and tidy.
safety_actions.Comments: The gate runners at the Arena get cleaned out weekly and before any major events. They gates are tried and any defect found are passed on to the FEM coordinator. The barriers at Leppings Lane get removed and taken back to depot every 2 months and are cleaned and jet washed before taking them back. Would suggest a box of disposable gloves are used when handling these barriers.

Just a suggestion for OCC. When doing a radio message/all stations with a road/junction/light location, some OCC controllers will only use the road/junction name. Newer drivers don’t always know exactly where that road junction is by name.
safety_actions.Comments:
Email sent to OCC from Dave M I think some of you may already do this, I know some of us do this with points, which is good practise and is really helpful to drivers, particularly those that are newly qualified i.e. "Gleadless tango zero one points are in a failed state...". "Hillsborough Hotel Bravo zero one points have failed and will require hand operating...". "Signals at Calver St/West St Jn, just after City Hall O/B, are all out...". "Signals at Fitzwilliam St/West St Jn, after West St O/B, are all out...". etc.
So please be mindful of this going forward and, if you're not alraedy doing so, let's start to include a little more location detail in our radio message.Kelly,   can you feed back to the person (if possible) that going forward OCC will try to remember to include a little more info. ref. the location etc. but if they, or any driver, are ever unsure of where OCC are referring to or they don't fully understand a message, then they must  not acknowledge via a status message and must ask for the message to be repeated, OCC will be more than happy to do so. 



Op's Standard C5.3 


All Stations Acknowledge



Addressees will be asked to acknowledge receipt of an all stations call by use of a status. OCC will check acknowledgement from trams and contact any relevant individuals that have not responded.

Drivers must only send acknowledgement statuses if the message has been clear and fully understood.

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation:
Segregated sections - If a tram stops suddenly, breaks down on the segregated sections of our system, there’s no way for the Network Coordinators to know how far behind a tram could be following behind and may not answer the radio call from the stationary tram in
time to inform the tram behind. This could cause a potential tram on tram impact, for example if a tram stops prior to ValleyCentertaiment o/b, the tram behind is potentially doing 40mph, the line of sight is blocked by the trees. suggest Trams that stop on segregated sections should send an emergency call to inform the Network Coordinators sooner and avoid a potential Collision

Tram Cabs - Again - asked over several years - heating vents in sieman cabs need

A woman got on the tram with her husband who was in a wheelchair she asked for my help lifting the wheelchairs front wheel on to the tram because she had a problem getting the wheel over the gap bewteen the platform & the tram. She explained that she wasn’t totally used to handling the wheelchair yet so was nervous about using the tram. Helped lift the wheel clear and they were on, we got talking and she expalined that the last time they had tried to catch the tram things hadnt gone very well  either becaue of the gap between the platform or because she nervous about getting her husband on the tram and was new at handling the wheelchair the wheels locked her husband ended up fallling on top of her and there was no one to help , the conductor felt unable to because of the no touch policy the passngers because well who knows, apparantley one young lass came and helped and cried while she was doing it because she felt so sorry for them i think that it is safe to assume  - gave her the details from lost luggage form and told her to contact Supertram about her experience and ask for reconsideration of wheelchair access or chnages to notices about ease of access of more information to help possible wheelchair users -  dont like the sound of that no touch policy i understand the need but not sure i can honestly stand by and not help in that situation
safety_actions.Comments:
trams are level access (notwithstanding any issues, as we know there are trams and or locations where they aren't always level) so there is no provision for assistance, nor will there be. Conductors are not trained (or expected) to assist wheelchairs, given the level accessibility.

Whilst we don't expect staff to assist, to be clear the no touch policy is not about assisting customers! I'd expect any colleague to use common sense around how that policy should be applied, specifically that it is in relation to altercations and ejection of passengers. It should never prevent a colleague from assisting a customer if the situation requires help (again, not that we'd expect them to lift a wheelchair or anything else they weren't trained to lift/move).

It's also important in such scenarios to explain how to board with a wheelchair, in that the customer should reverse on - never try to board forwards as the wheels are too small and risk getting stuck in the gap. The larger rear wheels will enable much easier and safer boarding. Similarly, when exiting wheelchairs should be reversed off for the same reasons. I will pass the comment regarding signs/guidance for wheelchair users to Rhi/Caroline.

DM reported that on leaving EP car park on Saturday evening at 21.15 and I was waiting for the shutter to lift. As the shutter was moving upwards I spotted a vagrant who had been sleeping in the doorway . I was waiting for the shutters to fully open and just about to set off and another vagrant appeared out of nowhere, I could have run them both over due to the gradient of the ramp and not being able to see clearly. Suggest Would it possible to have a mirror fitted opposite the exit and maybe some extra
lighting
safety_actions.Action Owner: James Stewart, Head of Customer Services
safety_actions.Comments:
Reply from  James Stewart  -One of you raised a query last week regards someone "sleeping" outside the shutter from the car park, on York Street. We picked this up today at Leadership and Nikolas and team will look at measures to mitigate any risk in that scenario. This includes the suggested mirror, if that can be achieved (there may be restrictions or reasons that can't be done) or potential for rumble strips or something else that might make it less attractive as a spot to sit/lay. 

In the meantime, the purpose of the email is to make sure you're all aware of the potential for someone to be outside the shutters so please be aware of the possibility. For now, I would suggest that when leaving the car park you give a quick blow of the horn to raise awareness of your presence.

Similar to buses, can we have window notices stating things like "Keep feet off
seats", "No pass means full fare", "Keep personal music personal" & so on? People
tend to accept such regs when written & would help reduce confrontation when
asked by we conductors!
safety_actions.Action Owner: James Stewart, Head of Customer Services
safety_actions.Comments: This isn't something we are considering at this stage. Unfortunately, we can't create signs for all scenarios and such signage alone will not stop issues arising. It may be something we consider when there is a more general refresh of signage and branding.

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation:
West Street inbound - I have some safety concerns regarding the heavy duty barriers that have been
placed outside West Street Live. I have been up to have a look and they are close
the tracks, and could pose a hazard especially on a Friday or Saturday if members
of the public walk or stand alongside the edge facing the tracks. Because they
appear to be higher than most people would step or climb over, it's possible
somebody would walk or run into the traffic coming the other way if they see a tram
approaching from West Street inbound, or fall into the side of a passing tram. It
could also cause delays to service / missed signals if trams are having to wait for
pedestrians to walk the length of these barriers to clear the swept path.
safety_actions.Action Owner: James Stewart, Head of Customer Services
safety_actions.Comments: Barriers have now been changed to lego bricks - the area is currently being monitored

Depot canteen - The Morphy Richards microwave is rusty on the inside. I believe it has happened from being cleaned with the inappropriate materials such as the green scrubbing pads in the canteen - Replacement microwave, designated cleaning materials for the new one so it does

Depot Shed - Bifold doors all routinely faulting. 8E been broken for over 6 months. Getting
towards colder months (especially annoying for us that work 24/7 whilst
management fast asleep at the weekend). No maintenance whatsoever. Doors
need to close. Common sense would say fix them in the summer. What do
management do exactly? This is a repeat issue where responsibility gets passed
from pillar to post. Doors need regular servicing to be preventative not reactive.
There is also absolutely zero heating in the depot shed whatsoever. Another thing
extremely frustrating when we work 24/7. Would be a different story if a managers
office radiator wasn't working in the middle of January. But you can work from
home to avoid that - Suggest FIX DOORS READY FOR WINTER. REGULAR SERVICING CONTRACT FOR
DOORS. PUT UP SIGNS FOR DRIVERS TO CLOSE DOORS AFTER BRINGING TRAMS IN. SORT SOME SHED HEATING BEFORE WINTER ARRIVES.

Important matters regarding our site facilities:
Flooding in the Tyre Shed: Reported by RSM, need to isolate the trapped outside tap to eliminate any leaks from the
feed. Additionally, the dead leg needs isolating to prevent the backfeed of bacteria.
MDPE Supply Issue: The MDPE supply, which also feeds the Infrastructure canteen, is egressing through a partially
opened manhole. This situation appears to have become permanent, which is in breach of the Workplace (HSW)
regulations. These regulations mandate that all floor openings, including manholes, must be securely covered to
prevent risks such as slips, trips, and falls, especially with said pipe sticking out.
Environmental Concerns: From an environmental perspective, the open manhole/cable pit can also allow pollutants to
contaminate site services. To address this, I recommend removing the temporary cabin (Infrastructure canteen) also,
which would eliminate these hazards.
Further regarding canteen facilities, the depot has two canteens (upstairs and downstairs) that can sufficiently cater
staff. Additionally, the East Parade canteen is available for mobile staff, with the option of staggered breaks too. The
total seating capacity for information at the depot is thirty-two.
Lastly, the tyre shed defect has been tacted down as a defect under reference DV160020.
Please can this be added to the HSTracker also please. Thanks
safety_actions.Comments: Email from Mark Blackwell 16/12/2025 - Tap was removed and all redundant waste water pipes and deadlegs removed - pipework removed and manhole cover securly covered with no pipes sitcking out Chased for response 02.02.26

Following the recent FRA yesterday the storage of combustibles were noted under the work shed gantries especially and in particular Depot WEST. 
This has been flagged before as a non conformance but further cemented now by the external fire risk assessor yesterday.
The current situation cannot be sustained and the following remedials on offer would rectify this:

The Gantries which are classed as a Mezzanine floor for the purpose of fire regs can either;

Fit a 1hour fire rated and slip rated SOLID flooring surface on the gantries with wired heat detectors on the underside either end connected to the main fire circuit.
(Storage underneath and current use can remain),
Remove all stored items and leave space under the gantries sterile.

Depot - Subject concerns regarding the intergrity of Supervisor logs and recommendations for improvement. Overview The current practice of maintaining supervisor logs for RSM in Microsoft Word format presents a significant
risk to data integrity and evidentiary reliability. As these documents are editable and lack version control or audit trails,
they are inherently vulnerable to post-event modification. This undermines their credibility, particularly in the event of
an investigation by third parties such as the (RAIB) or other regulatory bodies in the event of an incident.
Recommended Alternatives:
1. Digital Logbook Systems with Audit Trails:
• Implement secure, cloud-based logging platforms (e.g. RailSmart, eLogbook, or custom SharePoint solutions) that
automatically record all edits and user actions like the OCC log.
• These systems provide time-stamped entries and immutable logs, ensuring transparency and accountability.
2. PDF Archiving with or without Digital Signatures:
• Convert completed logs to PDF format with digital signatures to lock content and verify authorship.
• This ensures that once a log is finalized, it cannot be altered without invalidating the signature.
3. Policy and Training:
• Establish clear policies on logbook handling, including when and how entries should be finalized.
• Train supervisors on the importance of data integrity and the risks associated with editable formats etc.

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation: NEW Rsm Workwear material unsuitable for the work we do as the material change from 100% cotton which was originally used to 55% cotton 45% polyester puts a great safety risk of doing any hot works we use angle grinders . oxy /acetylene... and the wheel lathe can eject turnings at a very hot temperature. usually when doing hot works you will remove the hi viz vest u would wear. however the tee shirts and vests are literally a direct to skin workwear with no protection from hot works. even using a leather apron will not protect your body from hot works and potential burns - Suggest  - Workwear suitable for our daily role. the workwear previous was chosen to factor the use of hot works

Action Owner: Date
safety_actions.Comments:
Email from Dave Marrison - 05/11/2025- I've just listened to a radio call from Ben Riley (NTC) to the driver of the inbound tram (122) informing him of the incident and to pass with caution and only if safe to do so (or words to that effect), this is normal practise for OCC, to warn approaching drivers ASAP or stop the tram if deemed necessary. 

However, all drivers are trained to drive Line-of-Sight; driver sight lines are good on approach to this junction and there have been several bad accidents at this junction in the passed, so generally, I would say most drivers do take extra care on approach to this junction (as trained). I would also say that the driver would have had good view of what had happened and was happening, so would have passed with caution or stopped if not safe to pass, even if not pre warned by OCC.  

Tram CCTV shows inbound tram 122 approaching  and passing at a reasonable pace in my opinion and with caution.Email from Wayne Clay authorised to close this action

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation:
F1.12 It was identified that the speed limit on approach to the Staniforth Road 
Junction drops to 15 MPH, however this speed drop is beyond the 
pedestrian crossing, therefore technically the tram is able to continue 
proceed at line speed to this point. It is considered that a drop in line speed 
prior to the pedestrian crossing would be of a safety benefit, due to the 
provision of more reaction time for the tram driver and for the pedestrian 
alike. It is recommended that an assessment be carried out to assess if it 
is feasible to move the 15-mph speed limit forward of the pedestrian 
crossing or a drop in line speed on approach to the pedestrian crossin
safety_actions.Comments:
Response from Joe Wells was forwarded to Josh Keeling on 13/12/2025.

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation:
F1.13 SYMCA and the Sheffield City Council have the ownership of the 
infrastructure is and the highways, and SYFTL are the operator and 
maintainer of the tram network. It is not clear as a multi-agency 
requirement and this makes lines of accountability and responsibility 
unclear. This also alludes to potential risk and hazard identification being 
carried out in silos. That said there is an MOU between the affected 
parties, but it is not robustly managed. It is recommended that the MOU 
and affected parties review the MOU to reinvigorate the said document to 
develop a more robust partnership to improve the safety of the tram and 
highways interoperability
safety_actions.Comments:
Initially the MOU was not assumed as sufficient or efficient for airing issues of a joint nature i.e. as a multi-stakeholder environment for operational topics, although there was some limited interaction.  Since the incident on Staniforth Road, the MOU has now evolved into 2 meetings (engineering and Operations).  The operational MOU had now been scheduled by SYMCA to be conducted on a 2 monthly basis with a remit "To review the operational and safety performance of the tram network in relation to the highway environment, and to work collaboratively to improve the safety of the highway network in which the tram operates and improve the punctuality and reliability
 of the tram network within the wider highway network".  There are numerous muliti department stakeholder invitees to the said meeting to assure that joint highway and tramway issues can be discussed.  The Head of SHEQ and the SHEQ Manager are invitees.  As this is a newly developed group, the sessions will be closely monitored to assure that the relevant joint topics for highway, council and tramways are raised in this forum, this will include crossings as well as other operational topics that interoperate with highways
Evidence refers meeting dates sceduled for 03/02/2026

safety_actions.Action/Recommendation: Nunnery Depot - We have drivers going through green and bars at road junctions (not ped crossings) with no conflicting movements and then reporting to OCC. This goes against procedure but is probably the most sensible course of action. However as they have gone against a bar without permission these instances are logged with CCTV, reports and SIBAS requested. This is creating work for OCC, DMs and SHEQ for investigations. It's also leaving a mark against the driver in their file and creating extra work for training. When drivers report this most of them say they've done this to not stop on a busy road and/or have cars under or overtake the tram, or so that pedestrians don't walk out thinking the tram has stopped for a red light with cars still passing. As a professional driver they have made a decision that is procedurally wrong but is the most common sense approach to a problem. The driver has worked through with caution on a green light as OCC would have instructed and then informed OCC. The driver hasn't tried to hide the fact they've gone through a green and bar but the driver faces investigation for reporting it to us. This could cause drivers to stop reporting these instances which is a far worse situation.
safety_actions.Comments: 19/01/2026 It has been agreed that this action would need to include further depts - KHS was instructed by JK to ask DM to set up a meeting between the relevant parties to discuss further. Chased for response 02.02.26

Network wide - potholes are a major issue as the moment across the network it is understood by SHEQ team that temporary repairs are completed on the report of such a defect - however only tarmac fill can be used which is in most circumstances is ineffective and futile for the main reasons it is not a material that adheres east concrete - a hole can be filled an literally washed out two hours later - full  permemnant repairs can only be done by a partnering contractor during out  of service with the appropriate weather and traffic management becaue of this there could be a long lead time waiting for high risk potholes to be filled - the business is currently recieveing a high level of of successful public vehicle damage claims not to mention the high risk to pedestrian falls etc in addition sterling lloyd used as a substitute is also not suitable as not designed for filling potholes - Suggest having done some qualitive research onlie i wander if the business has ever or would consider trailling DEGAFILL for temporary repairs Details: https://degafill.com/
Success stories: https://www.bedfordtoday.co.uk/business/fix-and-forget-could-permanent-pothole-repair-be-the-soluti
on-to-councils-pothole-problem-5059501
If such a trial should arise, all work should be undertaken with the correct information, instruction and training.
safety_actions.Action Owner: Neill Barraclough Deputy Head of Engineering

incidents.Comments: Driver reports braking issue Norton avenue and park grange road inbound, driver reports tram not braking as should. Inspected all brake pads, brake discs, hydraulic pipes, hydraulic oil levels and all okay. Checked BCU’s and no codes logged. Checked sanders and all sanders blocked with wet sand. Cleared sanders but sander on axle 7 near side and axle 5 near side unable to clear blocked sand pipes. Replaced both sanders and now all sanders working. Whilst cleaning sanders and checking brakes found axle 8 off side earth return cable broken. Stripped cable back carried out a temporary repair and now okay. Took tram on mainline brake trials downloaded data extracted brake trials data put onto program and tram passed brake trials. Requested tram to be ran down neatherthorpe. OCC said they would take tram once early run in trams have come back onto depot.

incidents.Description of incident: 12:36 J RAMSDEN 463 14/01/2024 OTHER T106 J. LEGGETT (8504143) REPORTED TRAM SLID THROUGH INR I/B TRAM STOP DUE TO LRA. DRIVER REPORTED TRAM SLIPPING AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS. RSM ADVISED AND TRAM TO BE REPLACED. CCTV, SIBAS AND REPORTS REQUESTED. SIBAS: 148303. CLEANERS INFORMED AND TO ATTEND. EV/2024/00162
incidents.Immediate Cause: Tram driver passed signal at bar at the Infirmary Road/Bedford Street Junction
incidents.Underlying Cause: The tram was found to have sandbox no 8 blocked due to wet sand, also datums 2,6 and 8 were out of tolerance datums 6 and 8 were also  seized - driver failed to recognise the LRT aspect was at bar
incidents.Comments: Driver reported sliding through tram sto at INR I/b, driver reported unable to stop. Sand boxes reported to be full apart from one sand box. Checked mems and nothing logged at time of fault. Inspected all brake pads and discs and all ok. Inspected datums and found datums on axles 2, 6 and 8 out of tolerance. Hunted high and low for the datum adjusting spanner but unable to locate. Managed to free off datums on axle 6 and 8 due to being seized. Reset datums carried out several brake test and all ok. Checked sanders and found sander 8 blocked due to wet sand. Cleared sander and all sanders now working. Took tram out for main line brake trials and all ok. As a proactive measure requested tram to be taken down neatherthorpe and driver reported all ok.

REPORT REQUESTED. ACKNOWLEDGE THE TEMPORARY AWS MAGNET
incidents.Comments: The tram train was on the outbound chord in the area of the neutral section.  Just after the neutral section there is a permanent AWS connected to signal MS04S, then there is a temporary AWS magnet for the speed restriction further up the line on down/up Tinsley.

incidents.Description of incident: 22:29 J RAMSDEN 463 18/03/2024 OTHER TRAM 123 M. STOREY (745) REPORTED LEL O/B A CAR HAD RUN OUT OF FUEL BLOCKING TRACKS. PASSENGERS DETRAINED VIA ONE SET OF EMERGENCY DOORS. SYP IN ATTENDANCE AND PUSHED CAR OUT OF WAY. 22:44 CAR NOW CLEAR OF THE TRACKS.
incidents.Comments: The HBSC should reset automatically as the tram is coasting through the neutral section. On this occasion it did not, so the driver had to manually reset the HBSC on the second screen whilst coasting at 10 MPH.  At the same time, the permanent AWS 'pinged' indicating a green signal at MS04S.  The driver does not need to acknowledge this.  Immediately after that a lower pitch 'ping' is heard indicating that an acknowledgement of the temporary speed restriction is required.  As the driver was trying to reset the HBSC, he was a split second too late in acknowledging the AWS.  This then resulted in the AWS activating and the tram coming to a stop.

EV/2024/01217

incidents.Description of incident:
Was 2312-47 24/03/24 Sunday Days -CAT B drive – Continued from nightshift and tested to Meadowhall. Driving ok with no faults logged but noted a ‘clunk’ when passing under Sheffield Road bridge. Investigated and checked height of pan elbow, found to be slightly high at 605mm so adjusted as required to tolerance and retested OK. Requested OCC provide a mainline driver for further 2 x test runs. No faults reported.  25/03/24 Monday Nights

Pan check after damage to OHL found. - Checked pan and evidence of arcing/damage on elbow. Removed pan and put on jig. Noticed chains very slack at point of rest. Held down pan head whilst raising pan and at least 6 " of elbow movement upwards before lifting pan head. Tightened chains and adjusted cylinder lug until 3670mm achieved. Held pan head down and lifted and now only about 1 " of upward elbow movement prior

to lifting head. Painted damaged area and refitted pan. Checked elbow height on tram and 600mm

(used as training for M.P.)
incidents.Immediate Cause: The elbow of the pantograph contaced the OHLE
incidents.Underlying Cause: Incorretly set elbow height on exam - chain tension was not correct on the elbow of the pantograph - VMI does not state to check for elbw lift during setting
incidents.Comments: See level 2 report located in the issued section of the library

incidents.Description of incident: 18:50 Emergency call from tram 117, driver C Moran (8506977). Tram derailed at points T03 using  crossover, indication is second bogie derailed, no passengers onboard. RSM informed (M.Mead).  Cannot go to site until RSM vehicle back from Arbourthorne. XV Plus 150993 (tram) 150994  (points) 20:29 DM E Cooper. Drug and alcohol testing contacted. Advised OCC that we have no Taxi account for usage for crew reliefs. 20:29 N Wragg (on call): RAIB (Steve brake) has released tram 117 for re-railing. EV/2024/01682
incidents.Immediate Cause: The immediate cause was low speed climb out as a result of the right side wheel flange making contacct with the non criticalswitch  blade
incidents.Underlying Cause: Another underlying cause was the start stop by which the tram was driven over the crossover it is thought that this motion has contributed to the climb out by not allowing the flange to continuously centrifugal force to the critical switch blade to aid the redirecting of the tram over the crossover

incidents.Description of incident: Reported through customer services - I was cycling along West Street/Glossop Street, coming up to the Upper Hanover Junction (approximately opposite Welfare Pharmacy) at around 8.10am this morning (19/9/24) when a tram overtook me. This was extremely unsafe as the road narrowed before the tram had finished overtaking me, so the space foe me and my bike to fit in became very tight. I knocked on the window to ensure the driver was aware of what had happened and he immediately gesticulated angrily at me. It felt like he had been annoyed that I was cycling, and had knowingly squeezed past in an unsafe manner, and still felt that the situation was in some way my fault just because I was cycling. It was scary and unsafe, and I was angry that the driver didn't seem to understand this or take responsibility.
incidents.Immediate Cause: Cyclist not staying in the lay by
incidents.Underlying Cause: Cyclist error/driver not staying bac from the cyclist
incidents.Comments: This investigation was brought to light from a customer complaint

incidents.Description of incident: 18:25 T112 reports pedestrian walking trackside between Carbrook and Tinsley O/B side  towards Tinsley
18:45 T122 reports seeing the pedestrian near Tinsley tramstop - was clear for tram after

Driver Charlene Alexander Morrison conductor Chris Wright - Reported via customer care  - 31/10/2024  14:55  Yellow Tram on or around 14:55 the caller's daughter (aged 7) was out with her Grandma and they were boarding the identified Tram at Hillsborough Park to travel to Middlewood. For whatever reason, the tram doors closed before grandma could board and this left the little girl unaccompanied on the vehicle. She approached a conductor who we can  only identify at this time as an older man, to inform him of her situation.  The conductors response was "You will have to wait until the next stop to get off because the tram can't stop". At this point a passenger intervened - this was a female - and she said "You will be alright, I will wait for you until your Nanna comes on the next tram" This lady was prepared to complete the journey to Middlewood and wait with the child. In the meantime, Grandma has rung the caller (Mum) and informed her of the situation. Mum and Dad went to Middle wood tram stop and met their daughter at this point.It was only afterwards and in speaking with both her daughter and the passenger that the situation became apparent.EV/2024/04145
incidents.Immediate Cause: Tram doors closed seperating the two passengers
incidents.Comments: The driver was unaware of the situation the conductor did not follow procedure for dealing with a seperation duty manager Rwild & Dtingle interviewed the conductor once they were aware of the incident

incidents.Immediate Cause: The immediate cause of the rollback was due to the fact that the power controller was left in the power position as the tram came to a halt.
incidents.Underlying Cause: the incline of the tram stop helped to hide that the tram was left in power and had not applied the brakes -the age of the Siemens fleet does not allow for more robust verfication that the tram is at a standstill before satisfying the proving loop to enable the doors the 10% brake light was illuminated and was misinterpreted to mean that the brakes had applied

incidents.Comments:
25/11/2024 RSM Log Driver reported changing ends at MID and smoke filling the cab. Tram sent into end section and panned down. Met tram at Middlewood. Isolated cab 1 heater and brought tram back to depot. 

On return checked heater in cab 1 and heater working ok unable to get unit to fault. 

Investigated further checked wiring on unit and to the cab main heating contactor 61K11 on the roof but unable to find any short possibly shorting out the 100°C stat on the heater unit. Checked 100°C stat and after heating up stat is going open circuit as it should. Checked cab 1 main heating contactor 61K11 this in poor condition highly likely to of jammed/welded the contactor tips together for time of reported fault. 

Replaced the contactor for new, also fitted a new overhauled heater unit. Tested heater for cab 1 and operating as should.

On 18/12/2024], I observed a potentially hazardous situation involving live overhead lines and contractors working on a ladder at the depot shed main doors on Track 10.Upon arrival at the scene, I noticed one individual footing the ladder while another was ascending it. I looked up and saw that the overhead line was still live. Concerned for their safety, I immediately instructed the individual on the ladder to come down. Once the individual descended, Mark Blackwell informed me that he and Tom Harrison were in the process of isolating the overhead line. They then proceeded to turn off the power on Track 10.After ensuring the power was off, I returned to the shed and observed the contractor on top of a ladder on the other side of Track 10, next to Track 9.
incidents.Comments: Investigation was completed by MB - AB review comments were sent back to MB - investigation incomplete

incidents.Immediate Cause: Corrosion of the rail web and fot
incidents.Underlying Cause: Age of the rail corrosion aided by contamination (sand/salt) and feezzing tempretures for a substantial period would have been the final element required to result in a break
incidents.Comments: Service was immediately suspended when the break was identified bu infrastructure staff - a 3m closure rail with 10mm lift plates was installed withi hours of the break being discovered then then allowed trams to return to depot at the end of service and service to resume as normal the following day - daily track patrols were undertaken throughout this section whilst the cold weather persitied then eased to twice weekly - SYMC were updated the next day on the seriousness of the rail break and asked to escalate the proposed rail replacement for this area to Netherthorpe Road - Subsequent inspectiins and meetings havenow taken place and Mott Macdonald are now drawig a scope of works for Volker Rail to carry out the said replacement (rail only) - investigation needs to be signed off

JK Authorise
incidents.Immediate Cause: The collision occurred due to two pedestrians walking into the swept path of tram 105 at Meadow Street road crossing
incidents.Underlying Cause: The driver of the tram did not respond as expected to the hazard presented by the pedestrians until it was too late to take adequate evasive action - the pedestrians were in view for an amount of time which should have made it possible to stop the tram short or to reduce the impact, there is a lack of situational awareness and defensive driving on the drivers part  -  the reason for this cannot be explained by the driver of by the evidence provided by CCTV

incidents.Description of incident: 08:35 Tram 106 J Richardson (70452) HIL O/B reported a near miss  car coming through the red lights as the tram went to leave the tram stop no evasive action required by the driver

Either tram 202 at 12.00 or tram 205 at 12.27.  

She and her husband boarded the tram at cathedral thinking it was the Herdings park tram.

They were sat behind the driver in the 4-seat area, and the conductor was down the other end, and the driver was in the cab.

Has they hurried to get off again she had a fall,

The crew may not have realized she had fallen.

The lady is in hospital with a broken arm and is currently having an operation.

I took the call and the lady on the phone was upset, so asked for them to email me the details, but has yet we have not received anything.

Dave has requested for the cctv off both tram trains.
incidents.Comments: This concern was not reported directly to the crew on the tram - no staff witnessed the incident  - CCTV was pulled from trams within in the timeframe no incident was captured - insurers wetre notified of the incident and have had no further correspondance with the claimant.

A rail break was discovered  just prior to Shalesmoor road crossing on the O/B 6ft rail and within the segregated embedded area. The break follows the usual pattern for this type of break ) involving an Aluminothermic weld called a “Split Web Fracture”. The break will be monitored until we can get it removed and replaced with a closure rail being installed following an agreed process between SYFTL, SYMCA and VolkerRail.
